author: By Camille Baker and Christine Hauser
title: As Severe Storms Moved Through, U.S. Weather Warning System Faced an ‘Outage’
description: “Some warning services were impacted,” a National Weather Service spokesman said. By early Tuesday, things were back online.
content: As an outbreak of severe weather moved through the central part of the United States overnight into Tuesday, a key part of the nation’s weather tracking system experienced an outage, potentially affecting forecasters’ ability to warn people of dangerous weather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Smith
title: I Hope to Repeal an Arcane Law That Could Be Misused to Ban Abortion Nationwide
description: The Comstock Act is a major concern if Donald Trump is re-elected.
content: A long discredited, arcane 150-year-old law is back in the news in 2024, and that should terrify anyone who supports reproductive freedom. Last week at the Supreme Court, the Comstock Act of 1873 was referenced on three separate occasions during oral arguments in a case dealing with access to mifepristone, one of two drugs typically used in medication abortions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Did We Get the Joke? Thousands of You Had Some Thoughts.
description: Responding to our list of the funniest books since “Catch-22,” readers offer their own choices.
content: Nothing is funnier than unhappiness, according to Samuel Beckett, and publishing an excruciatingly short list of books deemed “the funniest” was bound to create a fair amount of it. We asked our staff book critics to choose 22 favorites among the many books that have made them laugh: They had to be novels written in English and published since “Catch-22” (1961), which we felt was a turning point in American literary humor. Then we heard from you on what our critics missed. In article comments and a reader questionnaire, more than 4,000 of you let us have it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: A New Voice in Soul Food Rises on Staten Island
description: At Shaw-naé’s House, Shaw-naé herself serves up Southern classics and a warm welcome to her “living room.”
content: “Do you trust me?” the chef asked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Endeavor, the Entertainment Company Led by Ari Emanuel, to Go Private
description: Silver Lake, the investment company, will buy shares in the Hollywood and sports firm that it doesn’t already own, valuing Endeavor at $13 billion.
content: Endeavor, the sports and entertainment company led by the Hollywood superagent Ari Emanuel, said on Tuesday that it planned to go private, nearly three years after joining the public stock markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael T. Kaufman and Dwight Garner
title: John Barth, Writer Who Pushed Storytelling’s Limits, Dies at 93
description: His sprawling and boisterous novel “The Sot-Weed Factor,” published in 1960, projected him into the ranks of the country’s most innovative writers.
content: John Barth, who, believing that the old literary conventions were exhausted, extended the limits of storytelling with imaginative and intricately woven novels like “The Sot-Weed Factor” and “Giles Goat-Boy,” died on Tuesday at a hospice facility in Bonita Springs, Fla. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: A Second Home That’s Far Away From It All
description: Two saltbox houses on the island of Newfoundland, in Canada, were hard to resist. What would be harder still: Renovating them without road access.
content: When Cailey Heaps wants to get away from it all, one place comes to mind: the island of Newfoundland in Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Avishag Shaar-Yashuv
title: Israeli Army Withdraws From Major Gaza Hospital, Leaving Behind a Wasteland
description: Al-Shifa Hospital lies in ruins after a battle there between Israeli soldiers and Gazan gunmen. Shortly before withdrawing, the Israeli military brought journalists from The Times to witness the damage.
content: Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City, once the fulcrum of Gaza’s health system and now an emblem of its destruction, stood in ruins on Sunday, as if a tsunami had surged through it followed by a tornado.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: U.S. Finalizes Rule Requiring Two-Person Crews on Freight Trains
description: The regulation ensures that the nation’s largest freight railroads will not be able to reduce the number of workers aboard their trains from today’s status quo.
content: The Biden administration announced on Tuesday that it had finalized a new rule that will require the nation’s largest freight railroads to maintain their current staffing of two crew members per train, settling a contentious issue between organized labor and the industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: 7 Aid Workers Killed in Gaza Were Known for a Passion for Helping Others
description: Gaza has been the deadliest place for aid workers since the Oct. 7 attacks.
content: To those who knew them, the World Central Kitchen workers who were killed in Israeli airstrikes in Gaza on Monday were described as devoted humanitarians who would do anything they could to help those in need.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: Africa’s Youngest President Takes Office, Promising ‘Systemic Change’
description: Senegal’s new president, Bassirou Diomaye Faye, took the oath of office in Tuesday’s ceremony. Close behind him sat the popular opposition leader who had clinched the win.
content: Still reeling from a whirlwind campaign, young people in Senegal threw jackets over their worn election T-shirts on Tuesday to attend the inauguration of an opposition politician who went from political prisoner to president in less than three weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Gunfire From Deputies Killed Teen Who Had Been Reported Kidnapped, Video Shows
description: Savannah Graziano, 15, was fatally shot a day after an Amber Alert was issued for her in September 2022. Newly released video and recordings show that she was killed by deputies.
content: Newly released footage and audio recordings from a vehicle pursuit in September 2022 show that a 15-year-old girl who had been kidnapped by her father was fatally shot by gunfire from deputies as she followed their instructions to exit her father’s truck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Alcorn
title: The Organ Is Still Working. But It’s Not in a Body Anymore.
description: Perfusion keeps a donated organ alive outside the body, giving surgeons extra time and increasing the number of transplants possible.
content: On some level, the human liver in the operating room at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago was alive. Blood circulating through its tissues delivered oxygen and removed waste products, and the organ produced bile and proteins that are essential to the body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: After Strike, Aid Groups in Gaza Are More Fearful Than Ever
description: “Gaza right now is one of the most dangerous places in the world to be a humanitarian worker,” a spokeswoman for Save the Children said after a strike killed World Central Kitchen workers.
content: Aid groups in Gaza said on Tuesday that they were more concerned than ever about the safety of their staff members there after seven World Central Kitchen workers were killed in an airstrike, saying that the deaths underscored the growing challenges of meeting Palestinians’ basic needs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Anjali Huynh
title: Trump Again Invokes ‘Blood Bath’ and Dehumanizes Migrants in Border Remarks
description: The former president has tried to stoke fear around immigration and border security throughout his 2024 campaign, as he has done in the past.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump again cast President Biden’s immigration record in violent and ominous terms on Tuesday, accusing him in two speeches in battleground states of creating a “border blood bath” and once more using dehumanizing language to describe some migrants entering the country illegally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Assesses Donald Trump’s Slumping Media Company
description: Jimmy Fallon joked that “Truth Social stock tanked so fast, they’re changing the name to Twitter.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Late Winter Storms Spare California From Drought Pain, for Now
description: A rush of precipitation lifted the state to its second straight year with above-average snowfall, though Gov. Gavin Newsom warned residents not to grow used to it.
content: The Sierra Nevada in California was so bereft of snow in December that skiers and farmers alike worried that a disappointing winter was sure to give way to a drought-ridden spring and summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: In the Magnificence of Iowa’s Glow, Albany Catches Some Shade
description: During the waning moments of Iowa’s victory over L.S.U. on Monday, a stray comment on the televised broadcast cast the New York capital in an unflattering light.
content: As Caitlin Clark and the Iowa Hawkeyes watched the clock wind down on their Elite Eight victory in Albany, N.Y., on Monday night, a sarcastic aside suddenly brought unwanted attention to the host city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Benjamin Mullin
title: Deal Talks Between Paramount and Skydance Heat Up
description: David Ellison, the founder of the Skydance media company, met with Paramount’s board of directors late last month to discuss the deal.
content: Shari Redstone is getting one step closer to selling her media empire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johanna Lemola and Emma Bubola
title: 12-Year-Old Detained After Fatal School Shooting in Finland
description: Another 12-year-old was killed and two other students were wounded in a country with one of the highest rates of gun ownership in Europe.
content: A young boy fatally shot a 12-year-old student and wounded two others at a school in Finland on Tuesday, the police said, a rare act of violence by a child in a country that changed its gun laws after earlier school shootings but where gun ownership remains widespread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Georgia Election Official Responds to Critical ‘Curb Your Enthusiasm’ Plotline
description: Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger sent a tongue-in-cheek letter to Larry David, the show’s creator and star.
content: Playing a maladjusted grouch on his TV show “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” Larry David manages to anger and irritate nearly everyone he comes across, whether they are waiters, casual acquaintances or even his closest friends.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Ethan Mollick
description: The April 2, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Ethan Mollick. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Protest Outside Netanyahu’s Jerusalem Home Turns Into ‘Riot,’ Police Say
description: Antigovernment demonstrators took to the streets for the third night in a row to call for early elections.
content: The Israeli police clashed with antigovernment protesters outside Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s home in Jerusalem overnight, on the third day of demonstrations calling for early elections and his ouster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Wednesday Briefing: Aid Workers Killed in Gaza
description: Plus, President Biden talked to Xi Jinping.
content: Israeli strikes on an aid convoy run by the charity group World Central Kitchen killed seven of its workers in the Gaza Strip. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized, and said Israel “deeply regrets” the strike. He called it “a tragic case of our forces unintentionally hitting innocent people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: Is Giving Farmers Millions to Kill Millions of Chickens the Way to Curb Bird Flu?
description: Big poultry farms have received millions of dollars for their losses. Animal welfare groups contend that aid reinforces inhumane cullings of birds exposed to the virus.
content: The highly lethal form of avian influenza circulating the globe since 2021 has killed tens of millions of birds, forced poultry farmers in the United States to slaughter entire flocks and prompted a brief but alarming spike in the price of eggs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold, Sarah Mervosh, Clare Toeniskoetter, Luke Vander Ploeg, Summer Thomad, Diana Nguyen, M.J. Davis Lin, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: Kids Are Missing School at an Alarming Rate
description: How the pandemic changed families’ lives and the culture of education.
content: Long after schools have fully reopened after the pandemic, one concerning metric suggests that children and their parents have changed the way they think about being in class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: ‘The Plane Is Fine’: An Airline Course Looks to Overcome Fear in the Skies
description: Anxiety when flying might not seem so unreasonable these days, but a British Airways program seeks to reassure the lightly nervous and the abjectly terrified alike.
content: No sooner had British Airways Flight 9240 roared into the air over Heathrow Airport than the cabin air was pierced by a sharp, scary noise, like an alarm or a siren. The power surged and then seemed to falter, and the plane became worryingly quiet. (Too quiet?)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Puccini’s ‘Butterfly’ and ‘Turandot’: More Than Appropriation
description: The history and curiosity behind these operas, both set in Asia, complicate often simplistic criticisms of borrowing and stereotyping.
content: A key relic of the genesis of Giacomo Puccini’s two operas set in Asia can be found not in Italy, where both works premiered, nor in China or Japan, where they are set, but — of all places — in Morristown, N.J.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Eyre Ward
title: A Journey to the Boot of Italy, With Murder, Romance and Ricotta
description: A Philadelphia chef goes searching for her family history in Jo Piazza’s sun-baked multigenerational tale “The Sicilian Inheritance.”
content: I am a novelist and a reader — all I want in the world is hot coffee and time to read and write. Since I was a tween devouring “Flowers in the Attic” and the Rabbit Angstrom novels — who let me read Updike as a kid? — I have been drawn to flawed characters, complicated worlds and propulsive stories that overwhelm me with uncomfortable emotions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
title: Biden Administration Presses Congress on $18 Billion Sale of F-15 Jets to Israel
description: The deal, which would be one of the largest U.S. arms sales to Israel in years, awaits congressional approval as criticism of the war in Gaza rises.
content: The Biden administration is pressing Congress to approve a plan to sell $18 billion worth of F-15 fighter jets to Israel, as President Biden resists calls to limit U.S. arms sales to Israel over its military offensive in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Joe Biden Is More Than His Age
description: Responses to an Opinion article by Frank Bruni. Also: Investing in Ukraine; Gabriel García Márquez’s last novel; America’s gun culture.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: How to Make Polluters Pay
description: A new Vermont bill would create a “climate superfund.”
content: Around the world, governments, nonprofits and even some everyday people are coming up with strategies to force fossil fuel companies to pay for their contributions to climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small and Marc Tracy
title: Protests Over Gaza Intensify at American Art Museums
description: A protest at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco led to the resignation of its leader and to a monthlong closure of its galleries.
content: The event at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in February was titled “Love Letter to SoMa,” after the San Francisco neighborhood that the contemporary art museum calls home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Larry Lucchino, Top Executive at Three M.L.B. Teams, Dies at 78
description: He oversaw design of new ballparks for the Baltimore Orioles and San Diego Padres, as well as renovations for Fenway Park with the Boston Red Sox.
content: Larry Lucchino, who as a top executive with the Baltimore Orioles and San Diego Padres oversaw the design of modern stadiums that evoke their surroundings — Oriole Park at Camden Yards in Baltimore and Petco Park in San Diego — and who as president of the Boston Red Sox helped to preserve Fenway Park for generations, died on Tuesday at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: Canadian Lawmaker Testifies Chinese Students Were Bused In to Elect Him
description: Han Dong, a member of Parliament who is accused of benefiting from the Chinese government’s help, testified at a public hearing on foreign interference.
content: A member of Canada’s Parliament testified on Tuesday that high school students from China were transported by bus to vote for him in a party election that is at the center of a federal inquiry into interference in Canadian elections by China and other foreign countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Take Me Out to the Gift Shop
description: For a lot of fans at the new Mets team store, game day is all about the shopping.
content: On Friday morning, at 11:40 on the dot, hundreds of Mets fans flooded into the new team store at Citi Field in Queens. It was the opening day of baseball season, and they were the first ones into the new space, located in the Jackie Robinson Rotunda, the grand entryway to the ballpark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley, Ben Protess and William K. Rashbaum
title: Gag Order Against Trump Is Expanded to Bar Attacks on Judge’s Family
description: Donald Trump had in recent days targeted the daughter of Juan Merchan, the judge overseeing his criminal trial in Manhattan, in blistering social media posts.
content: The New York judge overseeing Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial later this month expanded a gag order on Monday to bar the former president from attacking the judge’s family members, who in recent days have become the target of Mr. Trump’s abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: So Much Produce Comes in Plastic. Is There a Better Way?
description: As governments impose limits on plastic food packaging, climate-friendlier alternatives are in the works. Here are some that might be coming to a grocery store near you.
content: If it seems like plastic surrounds nearly every cucumber, apple and pepper in the produce aisle, it does.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The Appalling Tactics of the ‘Free Palestine’ Movement
description: What does it say about a cause that won’t weed out its worst members or stamp out its worst ideas?
content: Last week, Susanne DeWitt, an 89-year-old Holocaust survivor who later became a molecular biologist, spoke before the Berkeley, Calif., City Council to request a Holocaust Remembrance Day proclamation. After taking note of a “horrendous surge in antisemitism,” she was then heckled and shouted down by protesters at the meeting when she mentioned the massacre and rapes in Israel of Oct. 7.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Lee
title: In This Heartbreaker, Hard Choices Come With Hidden Costs
description: An editor’s ambition. A coveted manuscript. The gift of a cow. Lives and lies graze one another in Neel Mukherjee’s tragicomic novel.
content: Neel Mukherjee’s “Choice” is a novel full of characters deciding how much truth to tell. As in “The Lives of Others,” the author’s 2014 Booker Prize-shortlisted novel, we are confronted with subtle, powerful narratives within narratives exploring the gap between wealth and poverty, myopia and activism, fact and fiction. But here these themes deepen into an exploration of free will. A line from V.S. Naipaul’s “In a Free State” comes to mind: “The only lies for which we are truly punished are those we tell ourselves.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton, Vanessa Friedman and Guy Trebay
title: Who Should Be the New James Bond?
description: As speculation heats up around the casting of a seventh cinematic 007, Styles reporters consider possible candidates for a new Bond era.
content: The internet lit up last week over rumors that Aaron Taylor-Johnson, 33, might be the new James Bond. The next contender to play 007 has long been a source of conversation for the British media — chatter that started well before Daniel Craig even announced he was leaving the role in 2019. The frenzy for armchair casting has meant that virtually every British actor between the ages of 20 and 45 — including Tom Hardy, Tom Hiddleston, James Norton, Regé-Jean Page and Idris Elba — has been bandied about as a possibility. But rumors that Mr. Taylor-Johnson had been “formally offered” the role seem more pervasive than most.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Neal E. Boudette
title: Tesla’s Sales Drop, a Sign That Its Grip on the E.V. Market Is Slipping
description: Sales of the company’s electric cars dropped in the first three months of the year, even as other automakers sold more battery-powered vehicles.
content: Tesla appeared to be losing command of the market it effectively created after it reported a stunning drop in quarterly sales on Tuesday, raising fresh questions about Elon Musk’s leadership of the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Leifer
title: Israel Must No Longer Live by the Sword
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is wildly unpopular — but it will take a movement to unseat him.
content: The moment Israel’s devastating war in the Gaza Strip ends, the unfinished conflict within Israel over its future will begin again. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his right-wing coalition partners know this. That may be, in part, why they have set the improbable aim of “total victory” as the war’s ultimate objective, and why they have so far refused any deal that would end the fighting in exchange for returning the roughly 100 hostages still in Hamas captivity. After almost six months, this war is already Israel’s longest since Israel’s war of independence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: How José Andrés and His Corps of Cooks Became Leaders in Disaster Aid
description: Long before the killings of seven workers in Gaza, World Central Kitchen pioneered a new way to deliver emergency relief, using local labor and recipes.
content: World Central Kitchen’s rise as one of the world’s most agile and far-flung emergency feeding operations has been fueled by two powerful forces: chefs who know how to organize kitchens quickly in the most extreme circumstances, and the undeniable charisma of the chef José Andrés, a wealthy, well-connected restaurateur driven to feed people in disaster zones even when it seems impossible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Israel bombed an Iranian Embassy complex. Is that allowed?
description: Israel can likely argue that its actions did not violate international law’s protections for diplomatic missions, experts say.
content: On Monday, Israel bombed a building that was part of the Iranian Embassy complex in Damascus, killing seven people, including Gen. Mohamad Reza Zahedi, who oversaw Iran’s covert military operations in Syria and Lebanon, and two other senior generals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: How to Befriend an Introvert
description: A winning essay by Ashley Zhang, age 14.
content: This essay, by Ashley Zhang, 14, of West Vancouver, British Columbia, is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s new “How To” Informational Writing Contest for Teenagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Ruben Gallego, Democratic Senate Candidate in Arizona, Raises $7.5 Million
description: The congressman’s campaign said it had more than $9.6 million cash on hand as it looks toward a fall race against Kari Lake, a Trump ally, who has yet to announce first-quarter fund-raising figures.
content: Representative Ruben Gallego, the expected Democratic nominee for Senate in Arizona, raised $7.5 million in the first three months of the year, his campaign said on Tuesday, a significant sum for what is likely to be a competitive general election race in the battleground state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: inexplicable
description: This word has appeared in 107 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word inexplicable has appeared in 107 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 27 in “Helping a Child Navigate Grief? Open a Picture Book” by Elisabeth Egan:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: The Winners of Our ‘How To’ Contest
description: Over 2,200 teenagers submitted essays on how to do everything from fix a toilet to fight a kangaroo. We’ll be publishing the work of the winners all week.
content: Almost from the time our new “How To” Informational Writing Contest for Teenagers went live in January, we knew it would be a success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Yellen to Visit China for Top-Level Economic Talks
description: The Treasury secretary plans to address a surge of Chinese green technology exports during meetings in Beijing and Guangzhou.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen will make her second trip to China this week for high-level talks aimed at further stabilizing the relationship between the world’s largest economies as political rancor in the United States intensifies ahead of the presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess
title: Trump Asks Trial Judge to Step Aside, Aiming Again at His Daughter
description: Donald Trump’s lawyers argued that Juan Merchan should step aside because his daughter consults for Democratic candidates. The former president had furiously criticized her before a gag order.
content: Donald J. Trump, desperate to delay his criminal trial in Manhattan this month, has renewed a request for the judge overseeing the case to step aside, the latest twist in the former president’s attacks on the judge’s integrity — and family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: How Exercise Strengthens Your Brain
description: Physical activity improves cognitive and mental health in all sorts of ways. Here’s why, and how to reap the benefits.
content: Growing up in the Netherlands, Henriette van Praag had always been active, playing sports and riding her bike to school every day. Then, in the late-1990s, while working as a staff scientist at the Salk Institute for Biological Studies in San Diego, she discovered that exercise can spur the growth of new brain cells in mature mice. After that, her approach to exercise changed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Anderson
title: What’s the Quickest Path to World War III?
description: In “The Return of Great Powers” and “Up in Arms,” Jim Sciutto and Adam E. Casey consider modern-day superpower conflict through the lens of the past.
content: Every few months in the years that Donald J. Trump was president, Iran made a show of its ballistic missiles — the powerful rockets that can deliver nuclear warheads from one nation to another — and set off a small panic in Washington. The tests went like this: A missile flew up from one part of Iran, traveled through the country’s airspace and, ideally, blew up harmlessly in another part of Iran, hundreds of miles away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: World Central Kitchen Has Fed People in Disaster and War Zones Around the Globe
description: The group is a relatively new aid provider in Gaza, but it has garnered notice by making bold moves, like building a jetty out of rubble to bring aid in by sea.
content: Since its founding in 2010 by the chef José Andrés after a devastating earthquake in Haiti, the relief group World Central Kitchen has turned up at some of the globe’s biggest disasters, crises and conflicts, with the goal of doing what chefs do best: feeding people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: With Abortion Ballot Question, a ‘Path to Relevance’ for Democrats in Florida?
description: Rulings allowing a strict abortion ban, along with a ballot question on expanding abortion access, may inject new life into Democratic campaigns in the state.
content: Suddenly, November got a lot more interesting in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Lola’s Offers a Southern Spin on Filipino Cooking
description: Alaluna offers dry-aged fish with an Italian approach, Bon Bon serves up Swedish hot dogs and more restaurant news.
content: The chef Suzanne Cupps is honoring her lola (grandmother in Filipino) Annunciasion Rocamora Paraiso with this new restaurant that pays tribute to her courage during World War II. The menu reflects Ms. Cupp’s experiences growing up in Aiken, S.C., and working in New York with the chefs Anita Lo and Michael Anthony. Expect seasonal dishes like Southern stuffed clams, fried tilefish lettuce wraps with kohlrabi slaw, country rib skewers, and stir-fried egg noodles with early spring greens and silk chile crisp. The beverage director, Adrienne Vanni, has sought value on the wine list, with many options under $100 and several nonalcoholic choices. There is a bar up front and tables at green banquettes that follow back to the emerald tile open kitchen with a terrazzo counter where the chef will be at work. (Opens Thursday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron and Maggie Astor
title: Trump to Focus on Border as Democrats Eye Boost From Florida Abortion Ruling
description: Democrats, bolstered by a pair of court rulings out of Florida on Monday, have fresh optimism about their ability to center the campaign on abortion.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump will campaign on immigration and border policy today with events planned in Michigan and Wisconsin, two crucial battleground states in the Midwest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: What We Know About the Victims of the World Central Kitchen Strike
description: The group said one of the seven workers who was killed was a dual citizen of the U.S. and Canada, while the others were from Australia, Britain, Gaza and Poland.
content: The disaster relief organization World Central Kitchen said seven of its workers were killed in the Gaza Strip late on Monday in an Israeli strike on their convoy. It said one of the seven was a dual citizen of the United States and Canada, while the others were from Australia, Britain, Gaza and Poland. Here’s what is known about the victims, listed by homeland:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Iran Says the Deadly Israeli Strike in Damascus Will Not Go Unanswered
description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, said Israel would be punished for the strike, which killed three top commanders.
content: Iranian leaders said on Tuesday that the Israeli airstrikes on an Iranian embassy compound in Damascus, Syria, that killed three top Iranian commanders would not go unanswered. Government supporters took to the streets and called for retaliation against Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Jazz at Lincoln Center’s New Season Includes Tribute to Bayard Rustin
description: The civil rights activist’s life and legacy will be honored in a 2024-25 lineup that will also include spotlights on jazz history, and a rising star to warm up November.
content: Jazz at Lincoln Center announced its 2024-25 concert season on Tuesday, which will include performances that celebrate the 20th anniversary of the center’s Frederick P. Rose Hall, a tribute to the civil rights activist Bayard Rustin and concerts by Grammy Award-winning artists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Ukraine’s Arms Industry Is Growing, but Is It Growing Fast Enough?
description: Kyiv is aiming to build its own weapons to bring the fight to Russia. But it will take time Ukraine might not have.
content: Ukraine’s military had only one Bohdana artillery cannon in its arsenal when Russia invaded the country two years ago. Yet that single weapon, built in Ukraine in 2018 and able to shoot NATO-caliber rounds, proved so effective in the earliest days of the war that it was trucked to battlefields across the country, from the northeastern city of Kharkiv to the southwestern coast along the Black Sea and points in between.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman, Adam Rasgon, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Michael Levenson
title: Israeli Strikes Kill 7 Aid Workers in Gaza
description: The attack on clearly marked vehicles run by the World Central Kitchen shows how dangerous relief work has been during the war, and adds fuel to accusations that Israel has bombed indiscriminately.
content: Israeli strikes on an aid convoy run by the charity group World Central Kitchen killed seven of its workers in the Gaza Strip, setting off international outrage and underscoring the risks to humanitarian workers trying to alleviate a looming famine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Stuck Ships and Supply-Chain Inflation
description: Baltimore alone isn’t that big a deal, but is it an omen?
content: It has been a week since the Dali, a container ship, struck the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore. It’s still stuck there, and the images remain amazing, in part because the vessel is so huge compared with what’s left of the bridge. How could planners not have realized that operating superships in the harbor’s confined waters posed a risk?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Ireland Is Recovering Historical Documents Lost to the Flames of War
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 2, 2024.
content: “Archivists may not always know what they have, but they never throw anything out.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: China, Russia and Trump
description: What Beijing and Moscow hope to gain from a second Trump term.
content: America’s biggest adversaries evidently want Donald Trump to win the 2024 presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikki Campo
title: Is It Healthier to Eat Your Vegetables Before Your Carbs?
description: “Nutrient sequencing” is said to regulate blood sugar. We asked experts if the science holds up.
content: Q: I’ve heard that it’s best for my health to eat a salad before dinner. But if I’m eating vegetables regardless, does the order really matter?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Netanyahu Called Aid Worker Deaths Tragic and Unintentional
description: Also, Biden had a rare call with Xi. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Seven aid workers who had just delivered more than 100 tons of food to central Gaza were killed last night by Israeli strikes. The workers were driving in a clearly marked aid convoy, and they had coordinated their movements with Israeli officials. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized and said Israel “deeply regrets the tragic incident.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Adidas Stops Customization of Germany Jersey for Fear of Nazi Symbolism
description: The apparel giant moved quickly to block the sale of shirts bearing the No. 44, which resembled a banned Nazi logo in the uniform’s new lettering.
content: The sports apparel giant Adidas abruptly stopped the sale of German soccer jerseys created with the player number “44” this week because the figure, when depicted in the official lettering of the uniform’s design, too closely resembled a well-known Nazi symbol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Shogun’ Episode 7 Recap: Death Wish
description: As the walls close in around Lord Toranaga, his vassals and family look for ways out.
content: “When the legend becomes fact, print the legend.” Few cinematic genres have had as fruitful a conversation with one another as the samurai film and the western, so it’s only fitting to use an epigraph from “The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance” to sum up the central conflict in this week’s episode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rejects Bid to Revive Washington State Voting Map Said to Hurt Hispanics
description: A federal judge ruled that a state voting district diluted the ability of Latino voters to elect their preferred candidates.
content: The Supreme Court refused on Tuesday to reinstate a voting map for the Washington State Legislature that a federal judge had found discriminated against Hispanic voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Trump Denies Elections and Praises Rioters, but R.F.K. Jr. Says It’s Biden Who Threatens Democracy
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who founded his political career on conspiracy theories, condemned efforts to curtail misinformation on social media and said the Biden administration’s efforts to do so are anti-democratic.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump has refused to accept his loss in the 2020 election, painted as martyrs the supporters who stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, laid groundwork to deny the 2024 election results if he loses, and said he would be a dictator on his first day back in office if he wins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: Easy Dinners to Clear Out the Condiments in Your Fridge
description: Skip a trip to the store and clean out your shelves at the same time with these simple dishes.
content: Hi! It’s Genevieve, filling in for Emily Weinstein this spring break week. This change in seasons means a mix of warming meals and lighter, fresher ones. It also inspires me to start spring cleaning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Antolini, Wendy Dorr, Chris Wood and Jon Pareles
title: Beyoncé’s New Album Reviewed
description: “Cowboy Carter” is more than country.
content: There’s a lot to unpack in Beyoncé’s new album, “Cowboy Carter,” says The Times’s chief pop music critic, Jon Pareles. It’s a sprawling 27-track opus, and, despite being anticipated as a country album, it’s the work of an artist who’s willing to take chances, openly questioning the whole idea of formats, categories and genres, Pareles says. Here’s his review.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu and Rebecca Carballo
title: Thousands Without Power After Severe Weather Sweeps Through Ohio Valley
description: The storm system was blamed for two deaths, in Kentucky and Oklahoma. Forecasters expected the storm system to move into New England.
content: Powerful storms that swept across the Ohio Valley before moving east over several days this week were blamed for at least two deaths and still left tens of thousands of customers without power on Wednesday, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon and Aaron Boxerman
title: What We Know About the Israeli Strike That Killed 7 Aid Workers in Gaza
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel acknowledged on Tuesday a “tragic case of our forces unintentionally hitting innocent people.”
content: Seven aid workers with World Central Kitchen were killed in the Gaza Strip when their convoy came under fire on Monday night, according to the aid organization and Gazan health officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess
title: Trump Gets Bond Deal to Ward Off $454 Million Judgment, for Now
description: The guarantee means that New York’s attorney general will not be able to pursue Donald Trump’s assets and bank accounts until Mr. Trump’s appeals are settled.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump averted a financial disaster on Monday, reaching a deal that will spare him from paying a $454 million judgment in his civil fraud case while he appeals the penalty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: How Should I Be Using A.I. Right Now?
description: Give your A.I. a personality, spend 10 hours experimenting, and other practical tips from Ethan Mollick.
content: There’s something of a paradox that has defined my experience with artificial intelligence in this particular moment. It’s clear we’re witnessing the advent of a wildly powerful technology, one that could transform the economy and the way we think about art and creativity and the value of human work itself. At the same time, I can’t for the life of me figure out how to use it in my own day-to-day job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Ye Praised Hitler and Spoke of ‘Going for the Gays,’ Lawsuit Claims
description: A former employee sued the rapper formerly known as Kanye West, claiming a hostile work environment at Yeezy, his fashion brand, and Donda Academy, his private school.
content: Ye, the rapper formerly known as Kanye West, was sued Tuesday by a former employee who accused him of discrimination and creating a hostile work environment by calling Adolf Hitler “great,” disparaging Jews and saying that “gay people are not true Christians.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: 100 Years of Furniture
description: What’s your favorite furnishing?
content: The bean bag chair. The water bed. The sectional couch. Do you have a favorite piece of furniture, either in your home — or in your dreams? Which designs would you nominate to a Furniture Hall of Fame?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Rome’s Future Is a Walk Through Its Past
description: City officials kicked off a new project to create a monumental, pedestrian-friendly, archaeological area downtown, but some critics worry the plans puts tourists before residents.
content: Conscious of the weight of its illustrious history, Rome has managed to preserve an impressive number of archaeological monuments in its city center. The Colosseum, the Circus Maximus and the Roman Forum and Imperial Fora are just a few of the sites clustered in the city’s heart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: How Will Self-Driving Cars Handle Jaywalkers?
description: The city is introducing a permit process for testing autonomous cars on the streets of New York. The vehicles will face some unique challenges.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at Mayor Eric Adams’s recently announced plan to allow the testing of self-driving cars on New York City’s streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Checks Out
description: Billy Bratton has decided to extend his stay.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Farnaz Fassihi, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Israel Escalates Shadow War With Iran, and Trump Makes Bond
description: Plus, it’s the end of an era in Las Vegas.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Missile Test Hints at Greater Menace to U.S. Bases
description: The test, analysts said, may have involved a new intermediate-range hypersonic missile that is faster to launch and more difficult to intercept.
content: North Korea launched an intermediate-range ballistic missile off its east coast on Tuesday, an indication that the country was continuing to develop missiles capable of targeting American military bases in the Western Pacific.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris, Ben Sisario, Salamishah Tillet and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Beyoncé’s ‘Cowboy Carter’ Is a Vivid Mission Statement. Let’s Discuss.
description: The pop superstar teased a move to country, then tackled so much more. Three critics and a reporter explore her new album’s inspirations, sounds and stakes.
content: BEN SISARIO I don’t usually say this about news releases, but since Beyoncé says so little about the making of her art, the “Cowboy Carter” announcement was intriguing for noting that “each song is its own version of a reimagined Western film,” and that Beyoncé screened movies while she recorded, including “Urban Cowboy,” “The Hateful Eight,” even “Space Cowboys” (?!).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Biden Assails ‘Outrageous’ Florida Abortion Ruling as His Campaign Blames Trump
description: The president’s campaign moved to pin responsibility squarely on Donald Trump after the Florida Supreme Court cleared the way for a six-week ban.
content: President Biden on Tuesday called a decision by the Florida Supreme Court to uphold a restrictive abortion law “outrageous” and “extreme,” saying that it had effectively eliminated access to the procedure across the American South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock, Muktita Suhartono and Nyimas Laula
title: 5-Star Bird Houses for Picky but Precious Guests: Nesting Swiftlets
description: To lure swiftlets, whose saliva-built nests fetch high prices in China, people in Borneo compete to build them the most luxurious accommodations: safe, clean, dark and with pools for bathing.
content: With no windows, the gloomy, gray building looming four stories above the rice fields in a remote village in Indonesian Borneo resembles nothing more than a prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Iran and Israel Have a Long History of Clandestine Attacks
description: The regional rivals have for decades targeted each other’s interests, including with a recent strike in Syria that killed three Iranian commanders. Here are some other notable flash points.
content: For decades, Israel and Iran have fought a shadow war across the Middle East, trading attacks by land, sea, air and in cyberspace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: How to Do the Worm
description: A winning essay by Camille Gonzales, age 18.
content: This essay, by Camille Gonzales, 18, from Houston, is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s new “How To” Informational Writing Contest for Teenagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Maryse Condé, ‘Grande Dame’ of Francophone Literature, Dies at 90
description: She explored the history and culture of Africa, the West Indies and Europe in work that made her a perennial favorite for the Nobel Prize.
content: Maryse Condé, a writer from the French Caribbean island of Guadeloupe whose explorations of race, gender and colonialism across the Francophone world made her a perennial favorite for the Nobel Prize in Literature, died on Tuesday in Apt, a town in southern France. She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Have You Learned From a Grandparent or Elder?
description: Do you wish you had closer relationships with the older people in your life?
content: Have you had close relationships with grandparents or other elders? What memories come to mind when you think of them? What life lessons have you gained from your time together?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Iran says Israel struck its generals in Syria.
content: At least three generals and four officers overseeing Iran’s covert operations in the Middle East were killed in an Israeli strike in Syria yesterday, according to Iranian and Syrian officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: Drones Strike Deep in Russia, as Ukraine Extends Its Weapons Range
description: Ukrainian media and analysts, and Russian officials, said Ukraine had carried out the attack some 700 miles from the land it controls. Ukraine’s military and intelligence forces declined to comment.
content: Exploding drones hit an oil refinery and munitions factory far to the east of Moscow on Tuesday, in what Ukrainian media and military experts said was among the longest-range strikes with Ukrainian drones so far in the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Poor Nations Are Writing a New Handbook for Getting Rich
description: Economies focused on exports have lifted millions out of poverty, but epochal changes in trade, supply chains and technology are making it a lot harder.
content: For more than half a century, the handbook for how developing countries can grow rich hasn’t changed much: Move subsistence farmers into manufacturing jobs, and then sell what they produce to the rest of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Biden Critics Push Democrats to Submit Blank Ballots in New York
description: Activists pressuring the president over Gaza urge voters to leave ballots unmarked, since New York does not allow “uncommitted” votes in primaries.
content: President Biden will face another round of organized protest votes over his wartime support for Israel on Tuesday, when New York and three other states hold presidential primaries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: What We Know About the Iranian Commanders Killed by Israel in Syria
description: The leaders included Gen. Mohammad Reza Zahedi, the senior most leader in Iran’s armed forces assassinated since Qassim Suleimani was killed in 2020.
content: Iran’s supreme leader on Tuesday pledged to avenge the deaths of three commanders and four officers in Iran’s armed forces, one day after they were killed in a precision Israeli airstrike on the Iranian embassy compound in Damascus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle and Ian C. Bates
title: Warming Is Getting Worse. So They Just Tested a Way to Deflect the Sun.
description: A trial in California is testing a machine designed to reflect sunlight back into space. “All my colleagues hope that we never use these things,” one researcher said.
content: A little before 9 a.m. on Tuesday, an engineer named Matthew Gallelli crouched on the deck of a decommissioned aircraft carrier in San Francisco Bay, pulled on a pair of ear protectors, and flipped a switch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Safak Timur
title: 29 Killed in Fire at Istanbul Nightclub
description: The fire took place at Masquerade, a popular club that was closed to the public and undergoing renovations. Six people were arrested.
content: A fire Tuesday at a popular Istanbul nightclub that was undergoing renovations killed 29 people and injured one, the governor’s office said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Sticks. And the People Who Love Them.
description: Those who appreciate “something as basic as a stick” are sharing their enthusiasm through a newly popular Instagram account.
content: Stick Nation was born last summer, during a hiking trip to Arches National Park in Utah.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘My Family Owned Your House’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Yezha, my dad’s old dog, was missing one leg and all her teeth. Weeks before my son and I visited them in Warsaw, she stopped eating. My dad never let my childhood dog in the house. Yet, for Yezha, he’d fry naleśniki crêpes in butter and feed her the cheese filling when it cooled. He’d buy cabbage rolls at the grocery store, and we’d cheer when bites of meat stuffing made it past her gums. “Good Yezha,” we’d coo. My dad, twice divorced, grew up poor under communism. Wasting food was unthinkable. But he’d do anything to keep her alive. — Milena Nigam
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: A Lifetime Under the Moon’s Shadow
description: The late Jay Pasachoff inspired generations of students to become astronomers by dragging them to the ends of the Earth for a few precarious moments of ecstasy.
content: A total solar eclipse, when the cosmos clicks into place with the worlds aligned like cue balls, may be one of the most profoundly visceral experiences you can have without ingesting anything illegal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: What Happened to the Wrap Dress?
description: A pandemic, the demise of “girlboss” culture and new values around what’s “flattering” have made the classic design seem outdated to some.
content: By Amanda Sanders’s estimate, she owns more than 100 Diane von Furstenberg wrap dresses. She has been collecting the style since the 1990s, after she graduated from college.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: George Carlin’s Estate Reaches Settlement After A.I. Podcast
description: The estate had accused two podcast hosts of infringing on its copyrights by training an A.I. algorithm on five decades of Mr. Carlin’s work.
content: The estate of the comedian George Carlin reached a settlement on Monday with the makers of a podcast who had said they had used artificial intelligence to impersonate Mr. Carlin for a comedy special.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 7 Rainy Songs for April Showers
description: Hear tracks by Neil Young, FKA twigs, Love Unlimited and more.
content: It’s finally April, which means it’s time for those proverbial showers. We’re enduring another dreary, drizzly week of gray skies here in New York, but I’ve found a silver lining in all the clouds. Rather than rage against the rain, I’ve decided to make it my muse for today’s playlist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susanna Timmons
title: Can’t Make It to the Eclipse? Come With Us.
description: Like the moon over the sun, we have it covered. Here’s what we are doing.
content: At 9:51 a.m. local time on April 8, on Mexico’s western coast near the beach town of Mazatlán, the moon will begin crossing over the sun — the start of a total solar eclipse. As the moon continues its journey, the event will be visible across the United States and into Canada. More than 30 million people live inside the path of totality, according to NASA. And those who live along the route won’t be the only ones gazing skyward. Hotels started selling out in October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: The Caitlin Clark Show Rolls On
description: While off-the-court drama has raged in the women’s tournament, Clark and Iowa dispatched with their foils from last season en route to the Final Four.
content: One way to view the meteoric growth of women’s college basketball is through the career arc of its current protagonist: Caitlin Clark, the University of Iowa’s stone-cold mad bomber.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, Disney+, Apple TV+ and More in April
description: “Fallout,” “Girls State” and a “Bluey” special are streaming.
content: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of April’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Wolfers
title: I’m an Economist. Don’t Worry. Be Happy.
description: An economist explains why his lens makes him so much more optimistic about the state of our economy than the average American.
content: I, too, know that flash of resentment when grocery store prices feel like they don’t make sense. I hate the fact that a small treat now feels less like an earned indulgence and more like financial folly. And I’m concerned about my kids now that house prices look like telephone numbers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Baker
title: Is It a Blizzard? A Nor’easter? And What’s the Difference?
description: How to stay safe when the snow is coming down.
content: On March 1, 1888, a buyer for the department store Edward Ridley & Sons in New York City made an error. For $1,200, the buyer, John J. Meisinger, bought a carload of unclaimed wooden snow shovels — 3,000 of them — to sell at the store, the story goes. It was a “ridiculous low price,” Mr. Meisinger later wrote, but strangely timed. “Many of the buyers laughed at the idea of me buying snow shovels at the end of the season,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Nicholas Galitzine Wants to Prove He’s More Than Just a Pretty Face
description: Known for playing princes and their modern equivalents, this British actor hopes his steamy new drama, “Mary & George,” will change how Hollywood sees him.
content: “I’ve often found that the way people see me is very different from how I see myself,” Nicholas Galitzine said. “People attribute a pristineness to me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Regulators Force Another Microsoft Split
description: The tech giant is unbundling Teams from its Office software suite, as it faces mounting scrutiny on both sides of the Atlantic.
content: Microsoft is separating Teams, its popular video and chat app, from its Office software suite in markets around the world, broadening a split that began in the European Union last fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Joe Flaherty, ‘SCTV’ and ‘Freaks and Geeks’ Actor, Dies at 82
description: Mr. Flaherty first became known for playing a series of oddball characters on one of TV’s most influential sketch shows. He was later a familiar face in film and on TV.
content: Joe Flaherty, the comedic actor best known for his work on the influential sketch comedy series “SCTV” and as a father on the short-lived NBC ensemble series “Freaks and Geeks,” died on Monday. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz and Tiffany Hsu
title: An A.I. Researcher Takes On Election Deepfakes
description: Oren Etzioni was once an optimist about artificial intelligence. Now, his nonprofit, TrueMedia.org, is offering tools for fighting A.I.-manipulated content.
content: For nearly 30 years, Oren Etzioni was among the most optimistic of artificial intelligence researchers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Kim
title: John Barth, a Novelist Who Found Possibility in a ‘Used-Up’ Form
description: By merrily using fiction to dissect itself, he was at the vanguard of a movement that defined a postwar American style.
content: Nobody likes the comic who explains his own material, but the writer John Barth, who died on Tuesday, had a way of making explanations — of gags, of stories, of the whole creative enterprise — sing louder and funnier and truer than punchlines. The maxim “Show, don’t tell” had little purchase with him. In novels, short stories and essays, through an astoundingly prolific six-decade career, he ran riot over literary rules and conventions, even as he displayed, with meticulous discipline, mastery of and respect for them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Strike in Damascus Is an Escalation in Israel’s Undeclared War With Iran
description: Tehran promises major retaliation, and the danger of a miscalculation is ever-present. But neither side wants a major shooting war, given the stakes.
content: Israel’s bombing of an Iranian Embassy building in Damascus, which killed senior Iranian military and intelligence officials, is a major escalation of what has long been a simmering undeclared war between Israel and Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dylan Walsh
title: Let People Sell Their Kidneys. It Will Save Lives.
description: A regulated market for donations could help end the shortage of these organs for transplant.
content: I owe the past 25 years of my life to my father, who dozed under general anesthesia as a surgeon cut eight inches from stomach to spine, removed one of his kidneys, placed it on ice and sent it to a nearby operating room, where it was fitted into my abdomen. My brother had a kidney transplant the same week, six days before I did. His new kidney came from a man we never knew who had died in a car accident in the mountains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Tougher Security Measures Are Causing Upset at Guantánamo Prison
description: An effort to unshackle a detainee during legal meetings has put a spotlight on simmering tensions in the Pentagon’s secretive prison.
content: In a protest over tougher security measures at the Guantánamo Bay prison, a lawyer for the man accused of plotting the U.S.S. Cole bombing asked a judge on Tuesday to have the prisoner unshackled during legal meetings, invoking his torture by the C.I.A.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Halpert
title: 6 Hotel Pools Perfect for Swimmers
description: Many hotel pools are built with children and sun-seekers in mind: too short, too warm and too crowded. These, in cities across the U.S., let you get your laps in, in style.
content: Michele Heisler, 61, is an avid swimmer, putting in 45 minutes three times a week in a local 25-yard-long pool. But swimming while traveling can be challenging. “Most hotel pools are too tiny or too crowded,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Golembewski
title: It’s Always a Good Time for an Oyster Roast
description: How to host an outdoor seafood celebration during a Northeastern winter, according to the founders of the newsletter The Perfect.
content: The near lifelong friends Alexa Brazilian, Aaron Dickson Millhiser and Courtney Broadwater met in the late 1980s as children on Nantucket in Massachusetts, where their families would spend time each summer. They’d ride their bikes together and pass the days at Siasconset Beach, at the far eastern end of the island. In the years since, each has followed her own creative path: Brazilian, 43, is a writer, consultant and T contributing editor based in Little Compton, R.I.; Dickson Millhiser, 43, is a creative consultant, and a former head of men’s and children’s wear design at J. Crew, who lives in Manhattan; and Broadwater, 43, is an illustrator and artist based in Brooklyn. But the friends still keep in touch daily, often via a group text filled, alongside the usual news and jokes, with recommendations for things — from the best hot water bottle to an easy margarita recipe — that they love too much to keep to themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 2, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, April 2, 2024.
content: A picture caption with an article on Sunday about Ukrainian troops using marketing to attract recruits misstated the Ukrainian armed forces unit of which the Da Vinci Wolves battalion is a part. It now belongs to the 59th Motorized Brigade, not the 67th Separate Mechanized Brigade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Readers Share Their Favorite Places to See Art in California
description: Contemporary art with a hillside winery in Napa, a Roman villa-inspired museum in Pacific Palisades and more.
content: The Haggin Museum in Stockton has an impressive art collection, particularly for a city that has seriously struggled for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter C. Baker
title: The Case Against ‘Good’ Coffee
description: Instant coffee tastes … just OK. And that’s fine by me.
content: Not long ago, I went through a long period during which I awoke every morning with absolutely no desire to make coffee. Don’t misunderstand: I still wanted to drink the stuff. With a 3-year-old and 1-year-old waking me up around — if I was lucky — 6 in the morning, I relied on coffee’s sharpening effect more than ever. I was just tired of working for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kiuko Notoya and Mike Ives
title: Japan’s New Royal Instagram Page Forgoes Flash for Formality
description: No memes or spontaneity to see here, people. Just the usual official pictures of Emperor Naruhito and his family.
content: Anyone expecting the Japanese royal family’s new Instagram account to generate memes or showcase a new side of the world’s oldest continuous monarchy should lower their expectations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Klaus Mäkelä, 28-Year-Old Finnish Conductor, to Lead Chicago Symphony
description: He will be the youngest music director in the orchestra’s 133-year history, and one of the youngest ever to lead a top American ensemble.
content: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra, which has been led for decades by conducting titans including Georg Solti, Daniel Barenboim and Riccardo Muti, announced Tuesday that its next music director would be Klaus Mäkelä, a 28-year-old Finnish conductor whose charisma and clarity have fueled his rapid rise in classical music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: How to Find Your Balance
description: A winning essay by Chelsea Hu, age 18.
content: This essay, by Chelsea Hu, 18, from Andover, Mass., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s new “How To” Informational Writing Contest for Teenagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Fears Grow That Syria Strike Could Spur Retaliatory Attacks on Israel and U.S.
description: Current and former American officials say the airstrike on an Iranian embassy compound in Damascus was a serious blow to Tehran.
content: Current and former U.S. officials expressed fears on Tuesday that Israel’s airstrike on an Iranian embassy compound in Syria could escalate hostilities in the region and prompt retaliatory strikes against Israel and its American ally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Erica L. Green
title: Biden Talks to Xi About Conflicts, From Ukraine to the Pacific
description: President Biden aimed to keep relations stable in a call with Xi Jinping of China, but also raised concerns over Beijing’s activities around Taiwan, the South China Sea and Russia.
content: President Biden spoke with Xi Jinping, China’s leader, in a call on Tuesday morning that was aimed at addressing a variety of combative and cooperative issues, as the United States grapples with wars and other global crises, U.S. and Chinese officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri and Camille Baker
title: His Brownstone Is Worth $5.4 Million. Why Is His Tax Bill So Low?
description: Housing advocates and even some homeowners in wealthier neighborhoods say New York’s property tax system is unfair. A court case could force the city to make changes.
content: New York City is known for its pricey real estate, but some homeowners get an unexpected bargain: Property taxes on some of the fanciest, most coveted properties are often very low — at least relatively.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Before and After Images Show What Remains of Al-Shifa Hospital
description: The hospital, which was the largest in Gaza, stood in ruins after a two-week raid by the Israeli military.
